channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: U.S. and NATO See No Immediate Sign of a Russian Military Drawdown
item.description: Russia said it was continuing to pull troops back from near Ukraine, but Secretary of State Antony Blinken and the head of NATO said they had seen no indication of a withdrawal. Still, Western officials were cautiously hopeful for a diplomatic solution to the crisis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians in a pedestrian area of Kyiv, on Tuesday.

item.title: On the Edge of a Polish Forest, Where Some of Putin’s Darkest Fears Lurk
item.description: A U.S. missile facility in Poland is at the heart of an issue animating the Kremlin’s calculations over whether to go to war against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Decommissioned Soviet-era warplanes outside a U.S. base in the village of Redzikowo, Poland.

item.title: Defiant Protesters in Canada Brace for a Clampdown
item.description: The response of law enforcement in the nation’s capital has been painfully sluggish for many residents. But police signaled they may finally be ready to move in.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Vehicles blocking a road during a protest by truck drivers over pandemic health rules and the Trudeau government, in Ottawa on Wednesday.

item.title: A Charity Led By Prince Charles Is Investigated As Prince Andrew Settles
item.description: A day after Prince Andrew settled a sexual assault lawsuit, the police announced they were investigating a charity led by Prince Charles.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II, who is celebrating seven decades on the throne this year, at Windsor Castle on Wednesday.

item.title: Afghans Find Room for Debate on Twitter Spaces
item.description: An audio live chat feature on Twitter has become a go-to place for Afghans still recovering from the collapse of the former government and seeking answers on everything from what went wrong to what comes next.
item.dc:creator: Sharif Hassan
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shopkeepers in a deserted Kabul shop, checking social media on their phones to pass the time.

item.title: U.S. Warns Americans Abroad Not to Count on a Rescue
item.description: In Ukraine and Ethiopia, Biden officials have made clear that the 2021 Kabul airlift was a “unique” operation that won’t be repeated.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The city center of Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital. U.S. officials have stressed that, in the event of a Russian invasion, America would not rescue its citizens who remain in the country.

item.title: London's Troubled Metropolitan Police Service Searches for a New Leader
item.description: The change at the top comes at an awkward moment for the Metropolitan Police Service: It is investigating the government for breaking lockdown rules and faces scrutiny for its own scandals.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Cressida Dick, front left, resigned as head of the London police service last week after facing a barrage of criticism over reports of sexism and racism on the force.

item.title: Mudslides in Brazil Kill at Least 78 People
item.description: Intense rainfall caused mudslides and flooding that destroyed part of the city of Petrópolis, in a region where a similar disaster in 2011 killed more than 900.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The scene after a mudslide in Petrópolis, Brazil on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Administration Says China Failed Trade Commitments
item.description: In a new report, the administration detailed China’s violations of promises made both to the World Trade Organization and under a 2020 trade deal with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: Office of the United States Trade Representative
item.media:description: Shipping containers at the Port of Oakland in California, one of the main ports for receiving Chinese imports.

item.title: Harpreet Chandi Breaks Barrier With Solo Trip to South Pole
item.description: Harpreet Chandi is apparently the first woman of color to complete the expedition alone. She traveled for 40 days, pulling nearly 200 pounds of gear.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Harpreet “Preet” Chandi, a 32-year-old captain in the British Army, at the end of her Antarctic journey. For her, it was not just a test of her physical and mental resilience, but also a way to reclaim her heritage.

item.title: Prince Andrew’s Deal With Virginia Giuffre Leaves Many Questions
item.description: One question is who will pay for the settlement with the woman who accused him of raping her as a teen. But wider questions about his finances and behavior also dog the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Andrew last year.

item.title: Omicron Reveals Hong Kong's Covid Dilemma
item.description: An Omicron surge has exposed the weaknesses of a system that was once a world leader in containing the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Patients with Covid-19 symptoms at a temporary holding area outside a hospital in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: At Olympics, Nathan Chen and Other American Chinese Asked to Pick a Side
item.description: American athletes of Chinese descent at the Games are targets of patriotic and even nationalistic sentiment from both countries: sometimes adoring, sometimes hostile.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Eileen Gu celebrated her silver medal win for China in the freeski slopestyle competition on Tuesday.

item.title: Top European Court Rules E.U. Can Freeze Aid to Poland and Hungary
item.description: In a landmark decision, the European Court of Justice cleared the way for the bloc to cut billions in aid on the grounds that members are eroding rule-of-law checks and balances.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Monika Pronczuk and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary speaking in Budapest this month. Losing out on E.U. money is a very touchy subject for Mr. Orban.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: West Doubts Russia’s Claims
item.description: Russia said troops were ordered to pull back, but threats remain, U.S. and NATO say.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: The Ukrainian Army at a front line position near Katerynivka, in Luhansk Oblast of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Britain Will Extend Covid Vaccine Eligibility to All Children 5 to 11
item.description: Medically vulnerable children in that age group are already being vaccinated in Britain, following guidance the committee issued in December.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Preparing a dose of a Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine at a temporary vaccination center set up inside St John’s Church in London in December.

item.title: Putin's Long Table Sparks Dispute Over Who Built It
item.description: The oval behemoth, where President Vladimir V. Putin has met with world leaders, has become a subject of memes and think pieces, and now of a disagreement between furniture makers.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Tuesday.

item.title: Public Face of Canada Protests Is a Former Leader of a Secessionist Party
item.description: Tamara Lich, an Alberta activist, has channeled the truckers’ grievances, raised money and deployed social media to become a leading voice among the protesters.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Tamara Lich, an organizer of the protest, speaks with police liaison officers in Ottawa, last week.

item.title: Shark Kills Swimmer in Rare Death Off Sydney Coast
item.description: The fatal shark bite occurred on Wednesday near Little Bay. Mayor Dylan Parker of Randwick City, Australia, said, “To lose someone to a shark attack like this is chilling.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Little Bay Beach, in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday. In recent decades, Australia has recorded an average of one fatal shark bite a year.

item.title: Museum Security Guard Adds Eyes to Painting’s Faceless Figures
item.description: The guard at a museum in Russia has been suspended after he used a pen to draw on “Three Figures,” an avant-garde painting from the 1930s.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: The Art Newspaper Russia, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A detail from “Three Figures,” by Anna Leporskaya, after a security guard penned eyes on two of the faces in the painting.

item.title: Is Ukraine Cooling?
item.description: Three explanations for the latest news.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin at a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: Germany Aims to Lift Most Covid Restrictions by Spring
item.description: Now that the Omicron surge appears to have peaked, officials in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Slovakia said they too would drop all or most of their remaining restrictions in the near future.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Police officers checking vaccination certificates at a restaurant in Hannover, Germany, in November.

item.title: How Countries With No Snow Are Competing in the Winter Olympics
item.description: Several skiers representing countries with little snow are making their Olympic debut in Beijing, partly because of a diversity initiative that has generated controversy.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Zoran Marinovic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Skiers warming up before an Olympic qualifying race in Kolasin, Montenegro, in December.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Biden warns a Ukraine invasion is still possible.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden said his administration had not verified Russia’s claim that it was pulling troops back from Ukraine’s border and vowed to pursue a diplomatic resolution to prevent an invasion.

item.title: Inside Ukraine’s Cybercommand Center, Hours Before Attack
item.description: A day before Ukraine announced its Defense Ministry and banking servers had been hacked, our video team toured the country’s Cybercommand Center, where officials have been preparing for this scenario for years.
item.dc:creator: Michael Downey, Mark Boyer and Taras Ratushnyy
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Prokopenko, head of Ukraine’s Head of the National Center of Cyber Security on February 14, 2022.

item.title: Behind the Fractious Collaboration Steering the Canada Protests
item.description: The organizers include former law enforcement officers, military veterans and conservative organizers who are steering unrest that has sent shock waves throughout Canada.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Vehicles block a road outside the Parliament in Ottawa on Tuesday.

item.title: As Russia Welcomes Talks, Biden Warns Invasion Is Still Possible
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said he was pulling some Russian troops back from areas close to Ukraine, hinting at cooling the crisis, but U.S. officials say it is too soon to gauge his intentions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: A Ukrainian Army front line position on Tuesday near Syze, in the Luhansk Oblast of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Putin's Motives Pose a Challenge for U.S. Intelligence Agencies
item.description: Knowing the intentions of any autocratic leader is difficult, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who began his career as a K.G.B. officer, poses a particular challenge.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s calculus is likely shifting as he weighs the risks of an invasion against what he believes he could gain through negotiations, according to a U.S. official.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Russia Claims Some Troop Pullbacks
item.description: Biden warns that an invasion remains “distinctly possible.”
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia during a joint press conference with Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany on Tuesday.

item.title: Former Honduran President Juan Orlando Hernandez Detained
item.description: The request said Juan Orlando Hernández, who left office last month, was wanted in connection to a “violent drug-trafficking conspiracy.”
item.dc:creator: Joan Suazo and Anatoly Kurmanaev

item.title: In Italy, a Call for a National Investigation Into Clerical Sexual Abuse
item.description: Italy has so far resisted calls for an independent investigation into how the Roman Catholic church has handled these cases.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Italy has so far resisted calls for an independent inquiry, even after Pope Francis in 2019 held a landmark meeting on clerical sexual abuse at the Vatican.

item.title: On Ukraine, U.S. and Russia Wage Signaling War to Avert Actual War
item.description: Each side is trying to convince the other that the price of conflict is too high. It is a complex game played with deliberate ambiguity, raising the risk of lethal miscalculation.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: American soldiers deploying to Eastern Europe on Monday at Fort Bragg, N.C.

item.title: Ukraine Says Cyberattack Was Largest in Its History
item.description: Ukraine’s minister of digital transformation, Mykhailo Fedorov, said the attack “bore traces of foreign intelligence services.”
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Serhiy Prokopenko, head of Ukraine’s Head of the National Center of Cyber Security on February 14, 2022.

item.title: In France, a Racist Conspiracy Theory Edges Into the Mainstream
item.description: Valérie Pécresse, the center-right presidential candidate, used the phrase ‘great replacement’ in a speech punctuated with coded attacks on immigrants and Muslims.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:description: Valérie Pécresse, the center-right presidential candidate, said in a speech Sunday in Paris that France was not doomed to the “great replacement” and called on supporters “to rise up.”

item.title: Navalny Faces 15 More Years in Prison as New Trial Starts in Russia
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the jailed Russian opposition leader, faces charges of embezzlement and contempt of court that could extend his time in jail by 15 years.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, center, is shown on a monitor during a court appearance Tuesday at the penal colony where he is being held in the Vladimir region of Russia.

item.title: Indonesian Teacher Convicted of Raping Students for Years
item.description: In a case that outraged the nation, the founder of a school was convicted of raping 13 students, fathering nine children with them.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
item.media:description: Herry Wirawan being escorted to his trial at a court in Bandung, Indonesia, on Tuesday.

item.title: At Least 10 Dead After Spanish Fishing Vessel Sinks in Atlantic
item.description: Many are missing from a fishing boat carrying 24 people that sank about 280 miles off the coast of Newfoundland, Canada, on Tuesday, Spanish officials said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The Villa de Pitanxo, a 164-foot-long vessel, at the Port of Marín, in Galicia, Spain in 2019.

item.title: Vehicle Crashes, Surging
item.description: Traffic deaths are surging during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deepshikha Nag Chowdhury and Aditya Bhattacharya’s son Pronoy Bhattacharya died while crossing the street with his family.

item.title: Israeli leader, Naftali Bennett, Meets Bahrain Counterpart, Signaling Regional Shift
item.description: But the trip by Naftali Bennett, the first visit to Bahrain by an Israeli prime minister, also highlighted how the new relationship remains far from a society-wide compact.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.category: Khalifa, Salman bin Hamad bin Isa al- (1969- )
item.media:credit: Haim Zach/Israeli Government, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: In a photograph made available by the Israeli government, Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel, center, with Crown Prince Salman bin Hamad al-Khalifa of Bahrain, right, in Manama, Bahrain, on Tuesday.

item.title: Travel Trends for Spring 2022
item.description: With Omicron cases ebbing, the industry is looking for a significant rebound in spring and summer. Here’s what to expect, in the air, at the rental car counter and beyond.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: For the Games, Xi Ordered Up a Snow Sports Fever. Will it Last?
item.description: China said it succeeded on a vow by Xi Jinping, the country’s top leader, to nurture millions of winter sports enthusiasts. But will the interest last after the Winter Games end?
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:description: Speedskating lessons at a park in Beijing last month. China is seeing a boom in winter sports.

item.title: A World Away From Ukraine, Russia Is Courting Latin America
item.description: The Ukraine crisis has revived a struggle over Latin America between the U.S. and Russia, as Vladimir V. Putin seeks greater influence in the region.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: An aerial view above Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in October.

item.title: Germany’s chancellor meets with Putin as the tone of the crisis shifts.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany leaving for Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Requests Extradition of Former Honduran President
item.description: Juan Orlando Hernández, who stepped down as president last month, was recently accused in a drug-trafficking case in federal court in New York.
item.dc:creator: Joan Suazo and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Juan Orlando Hernández, the former president of Honduras. His party was ousted in elections last year.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine signals concessions as Russia mentions diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany during a news conference in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: Justin Trudeau Invokes Rare Emergency Act to Quell Protests
item.description: “We cannot and will not allow illegal and dangerous activities to continue,” Canada’s prime minister said in a speech to the nation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in Ottawa Monday announcing the emergency order.

item.title: Sweden Recommends 4th Covid Vaccine Shots for People 80 and Older
item.description: It also warned, as the country removes its pandemic restrictions, that the virus is spreading increasingly among people who are at elevated risk of severe illness.
item.dc:creator: Matt Surman
item.media:credit: Anders Wiklund/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: Waiting in line at a coronavirus vaccination site at Stockholm City Terminal station in Sweden last month.

item.title: Canada Protests Baffle a Nation of Rule Followers
item.description: The protests seem to challenge the cherished image that Canadians are moderate, rule-following and just plain nice. But was that really a myth all along?
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Brett Gundlock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in downtown Ottawa this past weekend. “This is a myth-busting moment,” one analyst said.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Talks of Diplomacy
item.description: Ukraine hinted at giving up its NATO ‘dream.’
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: A Russian submarine passing through the Bosphorus in Istanbul en route to the Black Sea on Sunday. Russia has reinforced its Black Sea fleet over the past week.

item.title: Canadians Donated Half of Funds for Trucker Protest, Leaked Data Shows
item.description: A close look at donor data — from crowdfunding campaigns to Bitcoin fund-raisers — reveals a cross-border mix of motives in support of the Canada convoy.
item.dc:creator: Mike McIntire and Michael H. Keller
item.media:description: Protesters in Ottawa on Monday.

item.title: Tone of Ukraine Crisis Shifts as Russia Signals Openness to Talk More
item.description: Diplomacy is “far from exhausted,” Russia’s foreign minister said, while President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said the prospect of his country joining NATO might be just a “dream.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at a front-line position in Krasnohorivka on Monday.
